content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												Many if not most of the negative reviews for Cities XXL seem to focus on one of two arguments:- an engine upgrade, even tho offering 50% discount to Cities XL version owners, should be a free patch according to some. Surely an interesting topic, especially if one goes by that even on lowest graphical settings a game in its endphase (and rig filling specifications) allegedly didn't uphold a proper game experience and should therefore fix an arguably essential issue for free. Myself I don't remember free nor discounted upgrade e.g. from Windows XP to Windows 7, to name an example of where there was apparently not really addition of features neither, while it was arguably laggy or such with plenty of stuff doing in XP. So such argument sure may seem valid a lot, but it does not really seem a proper review for the Cities XXL version anyhow.  - and argument about an "either - or" approach, which may be understandable if one wants to point out what may seem a better alternative but in my view doesn't justify a negative review as such. Meaning that just because someone may have more fun with one title surely doesn't mean that every other title of such genre is bad just becuase of that.  Anyhow, Cities XXL review of my own: Overally, I found the video game Cities XXL to be an enjoyable city building simulation, which offers complexity with not really need for tedious micromanaging (besides issue of that inter-city trading may have been made more streamlined by offering a global pool, but isn't really complicated as is). Various resources, possibility to build roads and large zones in different ways or plop individually, demands and desirabilities and population satisfactions (where eventual problems are mentioned with top bar where icons for industries, offices and workforces), plenty large maps in various setting (snow, beach, desert, greenlands), day-night cycle having various times of day with moving shadows and possible to switch inbetween (with moving cycle possible to be turned off), city overlay maps (such as for air or noise pollution, or particular satisfaction, and more), possibility to zoom-in to street level and as if walk around looking around, tutorial, possibilities with mods, all there.  In terms of performance I can't complain. With a what I would call mid-range rig (multi 3,2GHz (64), GTX 760, and 8GB RAM) and everything set on high I didn't really experience lag, even with city size having more than 10 millions of population. That is that zooming in or out quickly from top to bottom or vice versa did show a fraction of second lag, similarly sometimes on street level looking around, and at night when zooming out it took a moment for all lights to be rendered, but besides such it was fluent all the time. In around 90 hours of gameplay I experienced a few crashes, but such as far as I remember only when leaving a map, which was not much an issue to me since it successfully saved the map before the crash, so no building time lost with it.  As for gameplay more in detail:Cities XXL offers both sort of career mode for every map as well creative building possibilities straight on, meaning that one can go with starting with low density buildings and have further possibilites unlocked as the city grows in population (recommendable to learn the ropes and mechanics), or simply use in-game option to unlock most buildings straight away, or even called cheat to have e.g. cash added, or even have mod for such. Game is rather resource rich, ranging based on map limited resources such as water and food, to resources such as heavy industry and workforce split into 4 categories (with each category having housing of their own), which makes it on a larger scale a good idea to develop more than one map with each city specializing and trading with each other. But it is also possible to develop only one map-city while trading as possible and needed with Omnicorp (which is in-game a trading partner having unlimited resources to buy and sell, tho usually at a rate giving 2 resource tokens for 3 resource tokens taken, but also offering easy way to increase cash flow with resources traded from surplus). Specialization also brings possibilities to increase production of commercial resources a lot, meaning that map-total e.g. electricity production can be increased by 40% by placing one building only, which has prequisites to be unlocked. Many a resource usually requires other resources (e.g. heavy and manufacturing industry needs some offices, electricity, water, waste disposal, variously skilled workers, while needing to be near a freight connection such as road connection at map border, freight airport or harbour, and so on), which is why specializations are handy to use especially where the resource production requires upkeep (with every map supporting full specializations of max. two resources). Resources get distributed automatically within a city as long a road connection is there (including water and electricity). Inner-city mass transportation exists but unfortunately has only buses and subways (not counting mods) with no revenue from it (but limiting air pollution and usually decreasing travel time). Having to make those mass transportation lines manually is easy to do but may somewhat seem as micromanaging even tho with bus lines it requires no building of bus stops as in buildings taking up space at roads, and with subways it gives a map view where sub-stops are easily visible. Desirability factors (especially "quality of life") are important especially with higher tier buildings, such as offices and high-tech industry but also holiday hotels, which unlike business hotels require appropriate landmarks, which on some maps may be the whole coastal area in the beginning but usually require buildings (on maps with holiday resource). So while these things offer additional variety in terms of planning, I found the holiday factor in terms of gameplay rather boring quick tho since it doesn't seem that tourists have any impact whatsoever on retail nor leisure. So while it is easy to make a sort of eye-candy district for holiday hotels with retail and whatnot, in terms of gameplay it isn't really as if connected to each other as far as e.g. holiday hotels and retail is concerned, which is why I myself ended up trading for holidays from Omnicorp. While it may sound complicated that there are various resources with somewhat different requirements, it easy to keep track of, both in terms of having neat table overviews of which resources are lacking or too much off, but also since if e.g. offices lack business hotels the icon for offices in the top bar will turn yellow or even red with it telling what the issue is if one hovers with mouse over the icon. All in all, even tho not having a sort of endless career mode such as in terms of SimCity 4 filling a region map with cities for sake of having a view of a huge metropolis, plenty to do in career mode and even more if one enjoys creative building. Therefore from my side a recommendation for this city building simulator.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												When I saw this was coming out I was ecstatic. Multi-core so that you could build your biggest cities ever, improvements galore! Finally the time came to play, I loaded it up and....Cried. The tutorial is the same as the previous game, the game didn't change at all from what I recalled. I'm glad I didn't pay the full amount and yet I am also♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥about what they did. No changes what so ever. Same problems with the cpu and multi-core or lack of. If you don't have the game fine, but they pretty much just screwed with any remaining fans. I won't be buying another game from them.  Sadly this game comes from the same people who made Farming Simulator, a game I love to death. At least the differences between FS 2013 and FS 2015 can be seen and everything. Not so much here. Now I will be really looking at any "New" versions of Farming Simulator with a magnifying glass and WON'T be pre-ordering it like I used to. Probably will even wait until a Steam sale so they don't get as much of my money. How could they do this?  All this  'time spent' on this game here and what to show. Wow!  Money was already tough for me and now I'm out another $20 for the same damn game I had before! Oh well, I'll play this game whenever I decide to, but I won't be buying any more of their games at full price that is for sure.And before anyone says you don't have a powerful enough pc or something:Intel Xeon E3-1230 v3 @ 3.3GHz 4-core/ 8 threads (intel i7 w/out igpu, server grade cpu)16GB DDR3 1600 RamNvidia GTX 770 2GB OC GPU120GB SSD Boot3TB HDD Games and Misc.27" 1920x1080 displayMy other machine is a laptop:Intel i7 4710HQ 2.5GHz 4-core/ 8-thread16GB DDR3 1600 RamNvidia GTX 980M 8GB GDDR5 GPU 500GB SSD-Boot128GB SSD- Blizzard Games1TB HDD- Games and Misc.17.3" 1920x1080 DisplayThese machines can play anything I want them to and play the previous game just fine other than the issues of before. So the problem ISN'T my machines. They just blew it.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												I was an avid Sim City fan back in the day, I find the latest games stagnent and boring. I had to post this review due to the amount of negative reviews and people blathering on about how much they like Cites Skylines. I find the game play mechanics in skylines clunky, and for me it's difficult to get a city going with possitive cash flow, sure I could watch some more youtube tutorials, but I don't feel like it, I rather just play something else. Like Cities XXL. Things in this game work intuitively and I have a possitive feeling as my city makes money and I unlock achievments and more things to place in my city. My city actually grows and I have fun, isn't that how a game is supposed to make you feel? This is the modern day successor to Sim City 2000 and 3000 (and 4k I suppose :-)) that we always wanted! Don't hessitate to pick this up (esp on sale!) Boo to all the negative reviews and haters!

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I already owned Cities XL, This was the original version not the 2011,2012 or platinum, And for me i feel XXL it is a much better game. The game is much smoother, more buildings and maps than original XL and the workshop intergration is my favorite thing. I like the fact you can choose street options (for example building lay out 2x4 , 2x5 and so on), i like the range of maps and slightly differnt UI.The roads can still be a bit of a pain to lay and especially things such as bridges and tunnels and joining avenues to roads and expressways...I really do enjoy the game, however i feel it can be a bit annoying when objects won't go in a space and the game does not give an indecation of why. For me, i only paid £15.00 for this game and it is a lovely step up from XL, but i can see how it for those with the newer versions of XL it feels like nothing has been changed.My verdict is if you dont own any of the previous cities games, get this one- It is really good.If you own XL (original) or older and you can get this at a good discounted price (like £15.00) go for it :)But if you have the newer ones, it may not be worth it...

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												As a series long support of the Cities XL games, i am very much disappointed by this "new" version.Simply put:-It is the same game.Less simply put:-It has a new UI and a new music, but beyond that it is the same game, the same Graphics, the same performance issues once you start to get your city going, does not support the mod that fixed some of the graphical issues on XL.It also appears to have the same memory leak that plagued the other versions of this game, After about 35-45 minutes of play, my FPS started to slowly drop until i got to unplayable levels, save and restart the game and the FPS is higher again for 35-45 minutes.I do have to say that while the game is running well, it runs a little better than XL did, but, not well enough to rebrand and sell as an entirely different game, i was foolish enough to buy all of the "updates" so far because of the considerable discount, but really, it is not worth the price, as everyone else seems to suggest, its a pay for patch, that changes the UI for the game and adds steam workshop support.The maps and buildings are the same, EVERYTHING other than the UI and Music is the same, which is sad.I will be uploading some videos to youtube soon as a "review" of the game, i was going to make this "new and improved game" into a series. Not going to happen now i dont think.http://www.youtube.com/c/cxnjohn for later ref.EDIT:-They have said via their forums that there will be free DLC for people who got the game pre order, so this is positive, they also recognise that people were expecting more from the "new" game not just what appears to be the same game with a new UI.NOTE:-If anyone intends to use game footage on YouTube do not have the game music playing, your video will get a copy right claim against it, the vide of mine above has, so any future videos will be missing the game music.

number of helpful: 12 of 27 people (44%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Edit: TL;DR: If you're a fan of the series and don't mind that this is more or less exactly the same as Cities XL, then yeah its a nice "update" to buy. If you're not a fan and you're expecting something brand new, stay away.If you've played Cities XL, then you've played Cities XXL. This shouldn't have been a new game, this feels more like a fix for all the bugs that plagued Cities XL, but instead they introduced it as a brand new game.Pros:- Supports Steam Workshop now (YAY!)- No more memory leak like in Cities XL (that I can tell so far...)- Game runs a bit smoother than its predecesor.- Sky box leads to very pretty screenshots of the city.- New buildings and offers more in terms of environment and countering pollution.Cons:- It's still buggy, and still lags when the city population gets too high.- It feels like it should've been an update to Cities XL. - A handful of new buildings and fixed bugs doesn't make a new game, not really. Do I recommend this game based on what I see purely upfront? No, I really shouldn't. However, consider Cities XL and all its bugs. Most of it wasn't fixed with a simple patch because the issue lay with the core engine. Focus Home decided to tackle the engine problems and release the improvements at Cities XXL. As a city-building sim fan at heart, buying this at $20 was like buying really expensive DLC content. Is it worth it at full price? Not really. Why do I recommend this then? Because at the end of the day I still think this is a better game than Simcity.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												After 26 hours of play:I have a few cities, one over 300,000 people and the game does not lag like Cities XL Platinum did on a city this size. There are videos showing that there is a large amount of lag while actively tracing out large zones. I can confirm that this does happen, but it's not even remotely game breaking. As soon as the zone is drawn out and confirmed, the lag disappears. If you did nothing but build a city using this tracing tool and traced out only zones of a size that create significant lag, you'd likely fill the map in a matter of minutes. It's not something that many people are going to do and would defeat any sense of city planning.A second problem that people are complaining about is that the game appears to use only one core (CPU0). I have no idea why this is the case, but it simply appears to be a load-balancing issue on game startup and does not affect game play. The other cores are used, but for some reason CPU0 is favored. After the game is running, you can prevent the game from using CPU0, then allow it to use CPU0 again and from that point on it will evenly distrubute processing on all cores. Again, there is no noticeable difference in the game before or after this process.Overall, I like this game. I don't think the simulation algorithms are as complete as SimCity4, but I haven't checked out all the mods for Platinum and there aren't enough mods in Workshop yet for XXL. From what I've read, Platinum had quite a few mods that dramatically improved gameplay and improved simulation. Perhaps with time these will be brought over into Workshop and improved. As far as graphics and being able to lay out unique city styles/shapes, it certainly is better than what SimCity4 offers.As far as the company Focus goes, I think they did some things to earn their reputation reflected in the reviews for this game. This version of Cities is a step in the right direction, but the effort to enable multicore processing should have been made 2 years ago after they took over development from Monte Cristo. As for those giving negative reviews and outright lying in the review (especially about multicore processing and lag), they need to move on with their lives.Overall, for someone new to the series, I recommend this game. For those that are angry over past releases, this will be the game you should have received 2 years ago.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												There is not a great deal of difference between XL and XXL from a content perspective, but the game engine has been enhanced.  Large cities in XL were impossible to play even with two processors and decent graphics cards as there was no multi-core support.  The fact they are offering a 50% discount to owners of Cities XL makes upgrading worthwhile, just don’t expect much in terms of added content.  I have also noticed no bugs to speak of.  The game engine alone makes Cities XXL worthwhile as it makes the game far more enjoyable to play.  Don’t get me wrong, Cities XXL is the way Cities XL should have been after a patch.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												So, I wanted to give it some serious play time before attempting to critique this game. It recieved alot of harsh comments but all of them seem to be from people who were expecting some massive change from thier XL content. I have never owned Cities XL so I can say this XXL version is well worth the purchase. I love the global overview off the starts that allows me to basically build several citites on a continent and attempt to balance economies by trading between them. Its adictive...I find myself spending an hour or more on each city of mine daily to increase population and balance trade. No bugs or lag issues to speak of. I have a solid 30fps at all times even when conducting long roadway placements. One week in and I've got 4 cities up to 300,000 and each has a market niche to generate revenue. Once you find what your city excels at you can either trade to the game 'OMNICORP' for cash flow or use it to balance your other cities shortcomings. Stratigic thinking, decent graphics, larg scale cities & global economies make this a big winner in my book.

												Let's Start with "This is not a bad game!" if you are into city building. Having played this, Cities Skylines and Sim City (all of them) I can say they all kind of blur into each other and not one is perfect. Most of the negativity towards this game stems from the fact it is not much (if any) of an upgrade from Cities XL. I agree that it is not much of an upgrade. But that does not make the game bad it just means at the cost it's a bit disappointing (but still not bad) but if you don't have a previous version that negativity is void.The second thing that has also been complained about is the performance once the city starts to get larger. Well my quantum computer suffers none of this, and Skynot AI said "Any more complaints and I'm going to remove humanity" Has anyone looked at the interconnected complexity of any of these games?? most games when you are playing them have nothing going on when you are not in that area so of course they don't suffer this issue. BTW all the Sim City style games suffer this issue to some degree. It's more program than you can handle ;-)A few notes on the BIG 3 If you want the best graphics, smoothest gameplay, smallest city, lacking mod support get Sim City (5 aka 2013 aka EA why oh why) it's not terrible but it could have been the one!If you want the most options to select where you want to build in the world get Cities XXLBut if you want the game with the most mods get Cities Skylines (what I think is the best allrounder)BTW the hours recorded by Steam is not even close.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												If your here reading these reviews, you'll have no doubt already read a billion reviews which state some or all of the following:- Nothing new about this- They just re-worked the GUI- Buttons are slightly different- I want a refundand it goes on. So why do i like this game ? firstly i got it for 50% off because i already own a previous copy of Cities XL and admittedly  it's hard to find much that is different, i have noticed the splash screen is different and some UI additions but that's not really a great selling point. The biggest selling point for me was, i got it for 50% off, the maps are massive and Steam workshop is intergrated now.Though It's clear that not much is different and it has enraged an entire population of steam consumers who wanted something new and if you want a completley new game, don't bother.Buy this game for it's size and Steam Workshop, the devs are clearly supporting the modding community with this one and if things continue to go forward, like it has, this will be one of those titles that really benefits from the fans and the developers support of the fans. I have not experienced any issues with this game and definitely none of this lag that some people are reporting.Cities XXL is a game about creating epic cityscapes that span what seems like entire continents. I love how everything comes together and exploring the city you have created is so rewarding, especially when you get down to the street level. Obviously having a powerful rig helps in this case and it is worth having one, just to experience it.For those of you who would like refunds, it's too late. This game needs to be played with an open mind, the maps are huge and varied, which all offer a very diverse set of challenges. The game engine has been improved and the detail that shines from your monitor is glorious to look at.This may look like Cities XL of old but if you just give it a chance and embrace the community around it, you will enjoy your time playing this. If you want a new game with the ability to micromanage every small detail of the cities execution find something else. Let the vast environments of XXL suck you in and just enjoy it, i do.Lastley i would like to add the following point. People are calling this a glorified patch for $20 but let's just agree to say it is and it would seem like a massive rip-off to all consumers to pay for a patch. Now, just think about every new game these days, they offer season passess for atleast $25 and map packs/skins new characters etc, some of which are extras outside the season pass inclusions. With this $20 patch, you get a new game engine, maps, challenges, buildings and workshop support, additionally whatever they decide to add later and it won't cost you anymore then $20. For a game to be released at such a low price and not even ask for a single cent more for content, you really can't beat that logic.Nb. i am expecting alot of hate for enjoying this game, i challenge those to just play it for a couple hours, you will like it.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												FURIOUS:I loved playing this game ... three years ago. Now they are selling a patch for £15. I pre-ordered it with all my excitement and so much expectations. Soon it became my ultimate regret of buying Cities XXL when I read all the negative reviews on the launch day - I thought I would never download this game.However, it is obvious that no matter how people complain about Cities XXL, there will be refund from nobody, no party, no cats or rats. So I finally decided to give it a try - I paid bloody £15 for it! Now after 40 hrs play, I would say, they do patch the performance issues - that's just saying the multi-threading issue - yet millions of others are left undone!------------------------Calming down:There are thousands ways of making a new game over an old one. I have some knowledge about multi-threading and that is TBH nothing near complex - it is way too complex, and I can see that your effort on multi-threading has worked very well, but not been paid off. You can't simply ignore the remaining performance issues, such as memory leak, laggy zoning, laggy road placing, mysterious disappearance of metro/bus lines etc. People are complainng about seeing no change. It is SEEING no change. Can't you just make a better UI rather than changing colour schemes? Plus I don't like the current UI; check what Cities Skylines has shown us; Sim City 5 has a nicer UI as well.--------------------Sober thoughts:The game still looks OK. I can't say I am 100% admiring the graphics but I think it's reasonably good. The progression and contents are quite satisfying. Tokens and blueprints are very good endgame ideas.  BGM is a big thumb up! I absolutely enjoyed the main theme Sun Sleeper and many others. Comparing with Sim City 5, I wouldn't think Sim City 5 is any superior to Cities XXL apart from its graphics and UI. Sim City 5 had a lot weird AI and agents-related issues which harassed me a lot and finally kept me away from the game, while I don't see these issues in Cities XL/XXL, which is super good! And I guess this is the reason persuaded me to play this game, although I have already developed so much hatred towards the game developer.Months and months have passed since I left Sim City 5, you can't imaging much I would like to play a good city simulation game. When I saw Cities XXL offering such a generous discount, I clicked the purchase button with no hesitation and I even recommended this game to my friends. Now you presented me with a game that is still full of bugs and visually unchanged from Cities XL.--------------------Fair scores (out of 10):Graphics: 6            - variation in models is great, but the quality is bad.Music: 9.5            - bgms are being played repeatedly now.Game Content: 8            - enjoyable contents.Agent AI: 8            - no serious issues. I love my citizens.Performance: 5            - bugs are everywhere, please fix them.OVERALL: 7.5             - it's OK.----------------------Can I still recommend this game to others? No to anybody who has already had Cities XL. Yes to anybody who wants to play a city simmulation game.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												-- AFTER PATCH 3 EDIT --- You can now move with WASD!- RHM2 is working nicely in XXL!- Fixed stretched UI elements!- Mod community is growing (check XL Nation for even more mods!)- Achievements are hit or miss - sometimes they are unlocked... sometimes they're not... Have to reboot the game to unlock a new one every time...- The "Expert" mode is never ticked, still have to click it every time I join a city...- Looks like FHI is finally bringing this game together nevertheless...-- Original Review below --- Started game- Hoping for WASD- STILL NO WASD??- DANG0/10 would play SimCity instead!!But seriously, here's the rundown:- No WASD to move around, this is 2015 right??- Glitched interface, fonts streched... Ugly UI, like an alpha build- There are clouds now!! But wait.. you have to manually set the enviroment... no real weather... It's just there so your in-game screenshots look beautiful...- No day-night cycle yet? At least I haven't found it, gotta rely on mod on this too like the previous version...- BIGGER MAPS!! there's actually something new... ***(actually I learned they weren't bigger, but they can hold on much more stuff which before it couldn't)When should you get this game:- if you are new, feel free to try it out at your own risk. Overall gameplay is better than the new SimCity...- hold on to more mods. I'm testing them out from my 2012 version, most of them make the game crash.- when it gets the Realistic Highway mod. That should be standard by now...Side note - running fine under Windows 8.1 on bootcamp (iMac with crappy Intel Iris Pro 5200, max settings). But the game lags when building... smooth when just viewing and walking around... haven't made a ginormous city yet, so can't tell if it keeps its FPS high on max settings...

I like to play the game and add whatever DLC I chose and I like expansions. Also, for those who think I'm a paid employee of Maxis (R.I.P.)/EA or Collosal Order and Paradox; NO on all accounts. Cities: Skylines, while not perfect is a great addition to the city building genre. Hopefully Cities XL will get better. I would love to see an ultimate city building game where Cities Skylines, Cities in Motion 1+2, Simcity (2013), and Cities XL are combined.

												There are not that many real City Builders on the market and Cities XXL is one of them. I'm a big fan of Cities Skylines and I have + 6000 hours on Simcity 2013. content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												My Personal Review of Cities XXLFirst off, I put less than 2 hours playing CXLPlatnium, (which I did get on a deep discount), because of it's cam controls. Being able to get the latest version CXXL on a deep discount was a sweet bonus. I was hoping for a cam controls fix or at the very least, a place to adjust the sensitivity of the mouse movement. In spite of the cam controls, I spent no less than 22 hours straight playing once it was finished installing.An immediate reloading of the game from a shut down seems to bring about a downloading of data for the game each and every time it is re-loaded directly after shutting the game down (still looking into this). So, game re-load time is a bit slow. The cam controls are just the same as in CXL but I've decided to just do my best at learning to manipulate the cam and adjust to the super sensitivity of it. Alternatively, there are key commands that can be used to control the camming as well. During the first 20 hours of play, not once did the game ever crash on me. Kudos to the devs for that man. Not withstanding that at the time of posting this review, I found this tip posted by my good gamer buddy Monterico at 


YouTube™ Video: New Cities XXL Gameplay control tips - Learn to Fly 

			Views: 625		

			Whether you call it XXL or XL+ Here is a camera control tip I have been taking advantage of.		

Now while I've not put hardly any time into the previous version, there are at least 3 noticeable differences between CXL and CXXL: 1. A whole new interface. Getting use to it was not difficult at all. 2. Adjustable sky options which act sort of like mood filters. The Rainbow and Black Storm are my favorites already. 3. New Maps. Oh yes, the maps are freaking huge and there are some new ones albeit I do not know at the moment which ones they are exactly. In any case, if you didn't like small map sizes in previous city building games, you'll spend a lot of time trying to fill up a map in CXXL.A sinde note here is that of the first 22 hours of game play, it never once crashed on me.The fact that I spent 22 hours straight playing this latest version should tell you a lot about my first impressions of the game. I love being creative but prefer low impact games due to my failing health issues. Use to love shooter games but now, I just like a game I can play while laid back. I was asked often last night while streaming my game play, "So is it better than SimCity?" To answer that in a nutshell, no, it is just another city builder style game. Big maps or small, I don't care about that and find that some of the gaming community is a little to stuck up and demanding when it comes to what "they" think should or should not be in a game of this style. I enjoyed SimCity a lot and the multi-player online feature was what made the the latest version so much fun. While CXXL does not have multi-player, the shear sizes of the maps should keep me busy for a very long while till "No Mans Sky" (the next game I am holding out for) is released at which time you may find my solely playing that exclusively if not permanently. Until then, sorry Maxis/EA, you just lost a loyal fan till you can come out with a bigger, better SimCity. :pI wonder how long it will take to even try to fill up a full map in CXXL. Guess well have to wait and see. Looks like I might have to go after the 10 million population achievment at least.

												Since most of the negative reviews I've read here simply state that this game is not worth buying because it is the same as Cities XL, what does such a comment do to help someone who never owned Cities XL to begin with. content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												This was the first game in the series I bought, so I don't share the animosity others do about XXL being overpriced, but I still don't understand why people think the actual game is bad. It's actually very good imo. It's the most realistic city builder available, and the city builder which gives you the most flexibility in building. It can feel a bit lifeless in comparison to other modern city builders (notably CSL), and isn't that challenging, but it is my go to game for making beautiful, realistic cities. As far as technical issues, the game runs fine for me. Had it bug out on me once when I tried to place a blueprint structure. In my latest city, I've filled about half the map and am getting 25-30 fps on medium graphics with a marginal GPU (although I do have a high-end CPU). Bridges and interchanges are a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but other than that I find the user interface intuitive and easy to work with.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Personally, I like the Cities games. They're a cross between the odd social strata-juggling of the series' originator, City Life, and the more familiar 'build it and they will come' of the Sim City games, with the emphasis more on the building than the social stuff. That still remains an important core mechanic of the game though, so if you're looking for a city-builder with a bit more emphasis on the link between population and urban growth, Cities XXL is the one to get.If you've never played any of the Cities games before, this is the place to start, if for no other reason than that it's a technologically much smoother, more stable ride than its predecessors. If you already have a Cities X game, then you'll have to decide for yourself if it's worth the money (there's a discount for previous owners). XXL is currently the best representative of the series, and an excellent alternative to the Maxis games.

												Beautiful city builder, that does what it's supposed to: build cities, their interconnection and their hinterland. Don't be fooled by the haters. It's less 'gamey'than Simcity 5, less trendy than Skylines, but its visuals and organisation are superb. It's 3d.  BTW I've played its predecessors a lot. Eventually gave up on them to try something new and am soo glad I have now come back to CIties XXL. It's a relief after all the hyped up other games. This one's honest and beautiful. Of course it can still be imrpoved, but that's what they're slowly doing. Like a wordprocessor gradually evolves and improves - eventually beyond recognition - so does Cities. Each step is small, but important. With all those haters it makes me wonder: are they just jumping on the poppy bandwagon, or are they paid by a big company/competitor, or are they just being trendy i&*^ts?

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Good city builder with problems still. Tooltips are worthless, as you get further along past the 500k pop, demand for things can not be satisfied with the demanded building right next door. The exact building is a must. EX. Clicking on a residence shows need for education, open menu to schools and they have yellow and green borders around them. That means....er...um.. idk so I place the green one(10-18yr old) on an adjacent block wait a few ticks....nope, must be the yellow one(elementary), place it too right next to it, Wait a few ticks...nope. open menu again and see there isn't anything left but a school that is 10-14yr old and not 10-18yr old and place it and bam they are happy. What?... Retail is broken the same way. Demand is huge groceries but if you place a zone the game will put down a bar. Place a whole block and it will put a shopping mall, bar, and everything else but groceries, then commerce will start to go OOB because to much retail. No problem I'll sell excess to Omnicorp....oh wait they don't buy retail. SO a huge block of commercial next to residence and still dissatisfied cause they want a grocery store. Now you can manually place a grocery store, but you can only guess at what specific building they want by plopping down ...test ...destroy, plop down different one....test.Hi-tech says it uses waste, but in fact it uses the resource of waste removal, so it produces waste...er no cause if the waste removal resource is used up, they just go bankrupt.Size of fields do not equate to product produced. Ex. 30x30 forest vs a 4x4 park. Yes the 4x4 park @ 5k per tick reduces pollution better. So how about a 6x6 park? Nope, does nothing. Garbage dump 4x4 costs the same as one 10x10 and produces the same er... rids the same amount of waste and produces less pollution. Bus and Subways are designed so segregation of class blocks are the only cost effective way to use. Memory leak is still an issue, runs fine for a couple of hours post 500k, but then just gets worse until close and restart. Still not as bad as XL.Factories have to be placed at borders next to city connections or they will pollute and destroy your city and not be profitable for the lack of freight. They did add making building E+ friendly, but hardly ever stays when you switch from one city to the other. (there is a workshop fix, but that is not what I am reviewing)If you are going to buy and play this game, a pre-fab computer from Best Buy will not cut it. You need quality parts not new parts. The pc I use is 6 years old home build. Yes VISTA was brand new at the time. I play a lot of different games and have no issues at max settings.AMD Phenom II x4 955Radeon HD68708G ramWin 7 pro (blu ray playback forced the upgrade)Nothing special by today's standards, but runs game fine for hours.I'm not going to mention the UI, it is bad but there are other reviews that beat that horse to death.Recomend? Yes and no. On sale for $10 and you don't have XL, yes. Full price or already played XL, no.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												The game is MUCH better than any version before. Performance is way better, and by that I mean that it doesn't laaaaag after a city gets larger or after playing for a few hours. I know this because I did beta testing and I have hundreds and hundreds of hours playing Cities XL 2012 version. That laaag the previous versions had made a lot of people give up after reaching a certain population / city size. All that is now gone.If you played any previous version and liked it then you will love this one. If you are a new player and want a great city builder/planner that looks great and has large maps (11x11km) then look no further.The game by it self is fun for some time. Like any other city builder you will get bored after making a few cities. That is the case in any Sim City game as well. BUT!Thankfully the game has a great modding community which took this game to a whole new level.So you will never get bored because existing mods and new ones coming out on a regular basis will keep you hooked for a long time.There is a great comunnity forum that you just must check out:www.xlnation.cityDon't listen to the trolls saying the game is not better, it's the same as before etc. etc.Like I said I have hundreds of hours in previous versions and this one is extremely improved. Yes it is the same in many ways which is a good thing considering that old mods will be compatible. - It now spreads the workload of the game across all cores of the processor which makes it run smoother when the city gets larger. Is it true multicore or not doesn't really matter as long as the performance is better, and it is.- It now has DirectX 11 support- They added the workshop option- Now you can use fbx format to make mods- They added eco green upgrades for Heavy industry and Manufacturing buildings. Upgraded buildings produce much less polution.- It has some new transportation options (new park & ride bus system, new cargo airport)- New leisure buildings (including a large leisure airport, speed boat marina and a yacht marina)- New skyboxes to choose from (with clouds)- New parks- New polution reducing/enviroment improving buildings- New camera (just hit 'C' on the keyboard and use page up, page down / arrow keys / Ctrl button to move around)All in all this is a great game if you want to have FUN making/designing your dream city be it modern american style city or an older looking european city or even an asian style city. Or maybe all of those on a single map. The possibilites, specially if you use mods, are endless.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Over the past week, city building fans have waited patitently for what they were hoping to be the definitive city builder since SimCity 4. Unfortunately the opinions of players has been mixed at best. So is Cities XXL better than Cities XL or worse in every way? We have heard people say this is just a re-branding of an old game, so we decided to find out for ourselves.Cities XL first launched in 2009 and was a spiritual successor to City Life. The game offered expansive landscapes in which to build your dream city along with online capabilities (long before SimCity). However this did not live up to expectations, the online was a flop, the game suffered from poor optimization such as only using one core on multi-core systems and various memory leaks. Despite this, fans of the series have remained loyal. Despite its faults, Cities XL has offered a very fluid and flexible city building game.When Cities XXL was announced, it was detailed to have an all new engine, more low-level micro-management and various improvements including to performance. These alone should make it a worthy upgrade or entry point for a budding city builder.Well the first thing we questioned is the games engine. It is possible this is a new engine under the hood, but on the surface it looks very much the same engine as before. Graphically the game looks the same, albeit with a new black UI. The controls work much the same way and the menus are largely the same. So on the surface at least, the engine seems to have been tweaked rather than fully re-worked from the ground up.Performance wise, this game is far better. Our city of 425k inhabitants is still as smooth as when we started. In Cities XL Platinum, a similar sized city we had suffered from terrible frame rates and choppiness at this point. The UI is also more responsive than before. We did encounter some minor graphical glitches, mostly that at night, streetlights would illuminate a grid beneath them. But nothing game breaking.There are some new buildings to place in your city, like a pollution sensor and an eco-car dealer. There are not enough with too little function to add much weight behind a new game release, but welcome additions.Talking of pollution, this has been greatly tweaked and works more the way you would expect. It makes more sense than ever before to ensure your industry is far from residential areas, where as before it was more of a case of “Does City have Heavy Pollution? Yes, City becomes polluted everywhere quickly”.What we found most disappointing is there is not much of the low-level micro-management that was promised. What sets the Cities XL/XXL series apart from the SimCity series is the latter focuses much more on micro management and is more organic. In SimCity you say where you want residential, commercial and industrial areas, then depending on the desirability of the area would dictate what would be built there. This would not be static, you could have a luxury hi-rise apartment, but if crime in the area goes up this may become abandoned becoming an eyesore on your landscape. Cities XL/XXL cities generally remain the same, you will not find one neighborhood going from being desirable for Elites to suddenly becoming deserted.Despite this short coming, one major addition that will help over time to make the Cities XXL the city building game we have been waiting for is the inclusion of the Steam Workshop. I really look forward to seeing the modding community making new buildings, new functions, improvements, fixes and potentially new functionality.If you are a fan of the series, the current 50% discount off the price is very reasonable. Even not as a full game but £15 as a kind of expansion is not bad value. If you’ve never owned a game in this series and you want large sprawling cities rather than the small towns in SimCity then this is a game well worth picking up.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												After playing this game for a while, struggling to keep my people happy, I soon learned the trick that has allowed civilization to flourish over the past 7000 years. If you want to keep your rich elite happy, which you will need to do if you want to make anything more complex than an agricultural economy, place your elites housing as far away from the poor as possible while ensuring they do not need to share the same services. Make sure that their taxes are low and use the bulk of public spending on disgusing the crushing poverty on the other side of town. Don't worry about the unskilled workers happiness, I am yet to find the straw that will break the camels back.This game has provided me with a valuable life lesson in an entertaining manner - Keep the poor in their place, tip the scales towards the wealthy and everyone stays happy/ignorant.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												This is game is growing on me.. It's a mixed feeling at first because it starts out slow. I still would buy if it was released today though.I like that the cities are large (not like Simcity), but size isn't everything.. The game needs to be fun. The cities seem to run well so far, the Steam workshop is a very nice feature and will continue to grow, some added buildings, like the bridges/road options, freeways, etc. Zooming in and seeing things in more detail is nice, clicking a car and seeing things from that cars perspective going through the city is nice. I also want to mention that there are some cool building options.. I just noticed I can place certain restaurants, a night club, etc. There are a lot of cool new buildings that you can select and place; this is in addition to the standard ones that develop in zones. These extra buildings are growing on me, and really could help make this game much more enjoyable for me. There are tutorials in the beginning menu, and I suspect most people have not even looked at them. I am going through some of them now, and they are very nice. There also is a hidden menu on the right that shows more detailed information like traffic areas on the map, satisfaction, etc. If you hover your mouse way to the far right of the sceen the extra options come up; this is in addition the menu options of top of the screen..As the city gets larger it becomes more of a joy to play.. I am enjoying setting up the transportation system, seeing the city expand, demand change, etc.Things I don't like include the buildings don't develop like in Simcity which to me is a big deal (at least it was for me when I first started playing), the city progression starts out really slow (demand for goods seems to stay pretty low for a while which I think is where some people lose interest, but it gets a lot funner soon after), and the graphics/buildings aren't all that exciting to me (it is growing on me though like I mentioned in regards to the specialized buildings). Trade/manufacturing chains are to simplistic. .I'd say if you want a large city builder this could keep you entertained, but shouldn't be the only city builder in your aresenal imo. City Skylines looks like it will be good as well, Simcity was nice from the manufacturing/trading standpoint and it was fun, but small maps. If it were me and I either liked Cities XL but wanted better performance, or you like city builders in general I'd pick this up. I will say that we also live in an 'instant gratification' world, and 1 hour of gameplay isn't going to do it for those people; so expect to see the enjoyment increase as the cities grow. I will say I haven't developed a 'huge' city yet mostly because it starts out really slow, but I am now enjoying this game and see myself playing this more.

												I normally dont review games but I wanted to throw in my 2 cents on this one. I love City builders and this game in all its versions has sersiously frustrated me. It's a good game but just as you get going in the previous versions it would lag to an unplayable state.That being said, I want to note a few things for people that are considering buying this for first time as well as upgrading.1) So far im well past population where issues start occuring in the old version and I have flawless performance. So the folks on here and youtube that are stating there is no performance increase I'm calling BS.2) It's a GREAT City builder that got a bad rep because of past versions performance issues (this HAS been fixed)Now on to a few points concerning the company.Do I think they are shady and does it anger me that I had to pay 20 bucks for a patch? YesIs this the same game reskinned? YesIs it a bad game? NOThe people raging on Steam are simply♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off that this isn't a new game. I watched the trailers and any people that has played the previous games would know by looking at the trailers that it was the same game. What do you expect? They have released 3 "new versions" that were literally the same game. I didnt expect any less. I just wanted the performance fixed so I could enjoy the damn game for what it was and unfortunately I was forced to pay $20 to do so.Focus you should be ASHAMED for treating your players like that.They said a long time ago that the game needed to be rebuilt to get multicore support and maybe thats how the justified the "new game" this time. But its the same game WITH MULTICORE. People are saying there is no multicore support when indeed there is you can see it in your CPU monitor. Is it even across all cores? No, but it works and it runs great.So take the complaining with a grain of salt. A lot of people expected something different when the trailers clearly showed the same damn game and anyone that spent any time in XL knows it.Thanks and I hope this helps you buy or not buy the game. As for me, I am enjoying it and going to recommend it based on the fact I got it @ 50% off (still a♥♥♥♥♥♥off) and I am actually able to play it again. Also going to up vote to help counter the RAGE reviews.I want to DOWN vote it based on Focus being a slimy money grubbing company that treats their gamers like crap.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												The last thing I'll be able to understand is the negative reviews. Because of how poorly optimized the last Cities games were, people began developing some sort of bias that any future Cities game will always be bad. That's not the case here, anymore.Cities XXL is actually a big improvement from Cities XL 2012.I remember getting CXL12 back in 2013, and that was sort of my replacement for the awful SimCity game. Originally, I thought it was pretty cool. I made over 20 cities in a span of 5 months, but that's not the point. The game was no longer stable by the time my city was as big as a quarter of the map, and that's not good, of course. After a year-long hiatus from the game, I've wanted to play it again, but it's not even playable anymore. The game would randomly crash every 15 minutes or so, and that was very bothersome, and the game couldn't go above 30 fps, and it basically became a slideshow. CXL12 was ruined for me.But that was when I realized that I could get CXXL for a 50% discount. I've looked on their website and it says that they've improved their engine, which would make the game run faster. Being a customer of Focus for over 10 years, I knew they wouldn't lie to me, so on the day my father gave me a $50 Steam gift card, that was the first thing I bought with it.I began playing the game now and wow, they really weren't lying. There was definitely some improvements to the game's engine. Of course it still goes crazy after about 10 million residents, but remember, this engine is based off of a 2005 game engine that can only use one core, which is pretty impressive if that's true. My game was able to stay at a stable 60 fps even with a million residents, and so far, no crashes yet!This proves once again that a terrible video game franchise CAN become good if problems are fixed. I recommend this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Don't be scared of the poor reviews this game is getting...It seems that every single negative review is from people who are familiar with the Cities series who believe this is the exact same game as it's predecessor.Every single positive review is from first timers to the series, who all seem to enjoy it quite a bit.As a brand-new, first time Cities player, I am loving this game! I find myself much more immersed in this game than I am in any recent version of Sim City. The framerate chugs a bit when laying roads or residential zones, and the overlays for power, water, waste, and fuel could use a little work, but overall this is a big city builder/manager that is a lot of fun! Compared to the most recent Sim City (and all Sim City's for that matter), there seems to be less focus on things like utilities, police, fire, health, and education, but a much larger focus on managing unemployment rates and happiness levels. Happiness is affected by unemployment rates, utilities, police, fire, health, and education, so I guess it all comes together in the end. It's obvious that the primary purpose of the game is to grow as big as possible, and keep everybody content while doing it. Not a bad thing. I find myself wanting and trying and succeeding in getting bigger, before I am forced to try and catch up with my citizens by building luxury buildings to give them something to do, upgrading/rebuilding roads to handle the increase in volume, and trading with an NPC AI to help cover my shortcomings.And I'm having a blast doing it!Based on the size of the map when I zoom out completely, my city of 150,000 people, with a land area similar to that of an entire Sim City plot, is maybe a little less than one-fifth of the total area I can build upon. And I'm pretty spread out. For those who like to build one massive city, welcome home. If you are new to the series, I highly recommend this game. I understand why all of you fans of the Cities series are so upset. But for someone with no expectations, it seems to be well worth the time.

So rather you get it now or wait on it to go on sell I would recomend this game!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												EDIT: Definitely get Cities Skylines instead of this. Skylines is 100 times better and even has water physics and everything. However if you insist on getting a Cities XL game then XXL is the one to get.Coming from Cities XL 2012 to this, gameplay wise, its almost exactly the same game.Its got the same UI, just recoloured from blue to black (although it does look a little more tidy).Resources are still all the same as well as all the categories of buildings such as heavy industry.I have noticed a few new features and buildings in the game such as being able to edit how many plots the game places in the square building zones when building and choosing if the game places plots on one side or both sides of the road with the linear zoning tool. New buildings include things like the pollution sensors and electric car dealership just to name a few. Now whether these new features and buildings were in Cities XL Platinum, I have no idea. I never played Platinum or have seen any gameplay of it.The graphics look slightly better in this than Cities XL 2012 but its really not by much. I'm not sure if its me but the colours look a bit more vibrant in XXL though.Performance is much better in this than XL 2012. Focus Interactive have finally figured out that multicore computers are a real thing. In Cities XL 2012 there would be a noticeable drop in performance once your city hit around 50k population and would gradually get even worse as the population grew. In Cities XXL however, I have a city with 600k people and although there is a bit of a loss in perfomance it is no way near as bad as XL 2012 and still perfectly playable.For a new player to the Cities XL/XXL this game would probably be an 8.5/10. For a player who has owned previous Cities XL games its a 5/10 at best.So basically if you're new to the Cities XL/XXL franchise. Get this.If you've owned previous Cities XL games and are willing to pay for some really minor new features and multicore support then get this but maybe wait for a sale.If the performance of previous Cities XL games doesn't bother you then don't get thisI'm gonna vote yes to this game simply because of the fact that you can now build massive cities and still get a playable frame rate which in previous titles was almost impossible.TL;DR The performance is a lot better. The are some very minor new features. Other than that its pretty much the same as previous Cities XL games.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I've not played the previous Cities games but I am a fan of city building simulations such as Sim City. There's a lot of talk of this game being the same as the one previous, but as I haven't played those I can only judge it on what it is as an individual game. The maps are big, very big compared to Sim City, but then most maps on most games are bigger than those. The cities seem to run smoothly with no lag for me, but I have only had low density cities of around 100,000 people. It doesn't seem to go as indepth as Sim City though with regards to pollution, crime, health and other factors. However I feel that this game is more about building the largest rather than building the most perfect city. I have had trouble with loading up saved games and there has been some difficulty in placing roads but I feel that overall it's a fairly decent city building simulator if you haven't had a previous Cities game. In short, it's worth a purchase if you like city sims.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												For starters if you own Cities XL 2012 then you may find this game a bit expensive compared to what you will be gaining for the upgrade. It runs smoother than previous versions and does not sufer from the horrible memory leaks found in prior titles. I find the new UI to be a step in the wronge direction. Much of the text is hard to read because the colors are so close (black text on a grey background for example.) It does take up slightly less screen space so those with smaller monitors may find that a plus. As far as what is new:  - The new freight airport is a nice addition. - Also found in the marinas is a few new leisure options to make the waterways more usefull. - In the view panel you have the option to set a different background option and is nice for screenshots. - Some of the roadways are available from the start without turning on expert mode. This helps early game traffic managment and city planning.The main reason i recomend this title is for the people who have not played this title before and are looking for alternatives to games like SimCity. This title has the feel of SimCity 4 but with greatly improved graphics and trade options done on very large maps. It does however have it's own bugs and oddities though most are just anoying in this version and not game breaking. The steam workshop support allows for easy mod access. If you are new to the series watch some youtube video's and tutorials first (as mentioned before Cities Xl 2012 videos are still valid with only minor changes.) This game is not like other city building games and you will want to get used to the diferences.

Posted: February 6, 2015
												I'm new to the series, but I absolutely love the game. It's deep, fun, and a bit demanding of time. I play on and off line, and I could see myself lost in this for hours on end. Replayability is super high, as you'll learn from your mistakes and want to start over, or at least that's how I feel. My advice when you start is to not skimp on roads!!! Congestion becomes a real problem at around 20k, and then you probably have too many things connecting to small roads and would need to knock them down -- that is unless there is an upgrade feature, but I haven't found it yet if there is.The negative reviews appear to be an angry mob, rather than a coherent group of people experiencing real problems with the gameplay. I haven't experienced any problems, however, the one thing that did frustrate me was the no load of a self-saved game at menu, BUT once it loads from autosave you can load your Save, so that is not an issue at all. Though a load at MENU, would have been nice.I don't regret my purchase. And I am Very Satisfied.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												It is Cities XL. Those expecting an entirely new game will be disappointed. With that said, the game does indeed have multi-core support, and runs very smooth. It has full Steam integration, with Workshop support. It does have some new content, though much of the game is the same. Clouds, and other little features are sprinkled around the game.Basically, everything that they said was going to be added, was. It's worth the $40.00 bucks if you haven't played it before, as it is the prettiest city building game around by far. Its worth $20.00 as an upgrade, because multi-core does indeed work, and works well. Anyone hating on the game, saying nothing was added is wrong. By default, the mere fact that multi-core was added makes their statement wrong, as that is not something that is just easily tacked on. As it stands now, a lot of the bigger mods, such as RHM aren't compatible, but is already starting to be converted over. Is XXL perfect? No. Is it an improvement over Platinum? Yes, a big one. Is it better than unmodded Simcity 4 or the new abomination? Yes.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												More of the same. It's better than SimCity and doesn't suffer from *most* of the previous games' performance issues. If you like city building games it's worth picking up on sale. The game looks ok but still seems like the developer copy/pasted the old game into the new game. The multithread support helps however it still seems the game is jittery and has lots of screen tear issues (no vertical sync option?). I have an i7-4770k and every game I have thrown at it runs smooth except this game, the screen tears are really just annoying more than anything. The game is great for capturing single screenshots of HUGE cities and the trading works well (although can be easily exploited). I don't yet have a lot of hours however I can already see it's almost identical to the previous games, of which I own them all.Overall I have liked the previous games and this is the best of the series. That being said, it's more of the same old game. I'll dump 50 hours or so into it within the next few months, but it's not going to blow me away. It's still better than SimCity though since I can have a functional city larger than the size of a single neighborhood. I recommend the game if it's on sale, if it's not, you wouldn't be missing much by picking up the older versions.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												{Owner of Previous City XL Titles}All things considered this is a pretty decent game, considering the city building genre has traditionally been a limited market. The new additions were merely evolutionary and cosmetic and thats ok; more of a DLC than a new experience. Worth the $20 pre order in my case.GOOD - Cleaner Interface, new building filter meu, atmospheric back drops (skies), environmental enhancements simply provide a generic improvement to areas around them (new parks, ?sensors?, etc.), a new freight airport, new cruise ship port, and soundtrack.BAD - Persistent bugs - roundabouts and highway interfaces fail to visualize traffic flow (cars disappear), will take awhile before moddings translate from previous titles (if you find alot of use from modding it may be wise to wait a bit), core fan requests still not available (i.e. missing intercity/above ground rail infrastructure)BOTTOM LINE: If you enjoy city building games then the game is worth its weight. Is it perfect? No. The game excels in such a way that its shortcomings are glaring; hence the frustrations lobbed its way. Whether Focus Home Interactive should/could do more will fall to the sea of opinions. Decide for you. And while I certainly fall in the camp that asks more of FHI, I still find enjoyment in the title's current state; the Black Swan that it is. What can I say . . . I like city building.

												The improvements in this game are great. I like how they added a lot more detail to the game and also made it utilize more than a single core. content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												It's only just come out (5th Feb 2015) but already I've played it enough to know it's an almost exact clone of the predeecing version (XL Platinum), the only difference being that the GUI has had a "Windows 8.1" makeover (it's turned funeral grey and is bordeless).  Otherwise, it's the same game it ever was, complete with stutters and jutters and rather poorly realised calculation tables that means as the city gets larger, the whole thing slows down.  This was always a talking point of earlier versions, but looks like the programmers have simply ignored all suggestions (yet again...!).  I've yet to get a really big city going, but a medium sized one is already showing signs of buckling under the claculations strain.Despite this, it's still a better game (in my view) than it's big-company rival Sim City, with its kiddy graphics and sandbox square townships.  It will appeal to those who just want to get on with building a city, along more accurate simulation models.  Just be prepared to fill your swear box when things start grinding to a standstill.  Oh, and they've changed the muzak yet again.  Nice touch that.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Ok... This game has gotten a lot of bad press from some very angry people, but I have to say... I LOVE THIS GAME!!! The positives:  - The graphic are great! - Things are running smoothly on my machine - I like driving through my city and standing on top of buildings looking at what I've done - The farms are expansive - It's really fun seeing all the different buildings - It's challenging trying to balance the city needs, especially trying to solve traffic issues - I love that services are distance-based and not radial, and they have decent coverage - There are so many things to do and new things unlocking all the time - The tutorials help a LOT - I haven't encountered a single bug.The negatives: - The MUSIC... omg - It's lacking some flexibility with the roads (tight angles, on/off ramps... maybe I just haven't gotten that far) - I don't like having to bulldoze long stretches of roads to make minor tweaks and to upgrade roads. - It's more difficult than I thought to master the mechanics. - The "look around" feature with the mouse wheel is WAY too sensitive. It's an art form to pan where you want. - I wish I could choose whether or not to have suspension beams on my high-traffic viaducts. - It's kind of a pain having to drill down into each tool (and having it reset the default tool)The neutrals: - The controls are fine once you know how to use them, although some people are REALLY passionate about this. - The UI is intuitive and clean in my opinion. I used the tutorial so I know where everything is.Overall, I REALLY like this game so far, although I do get what people are saying about not being able to "connect" with the game. Something is lacking there, but I can't put my finger on it. Still I find it very enjoyable. I personally think the developers did a great job because the game is beautiful. I can imagine the challenges they went through. I think people are nitpicking over some very small things, but maybe I feel that way because I haven't owned a previous version of this game (and that was by choice, not from a lack of knowledge about the game).

number of helpful: 3 of 24 people (13%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												If you are a New to Cities Series Games, Read everything. It will give you some insight about the Thumbs down.If you are an avid Cities XL player Skip this first part.New to Cities? This game is for you. Stop reading the thumbs down reviews. they really aren't helpful….period. If you're looking at it, it's most likely because you are looking for a more original city building simulation game. Its simple mechanics allow you to focus more on the city building while easily managing economic efficiency.Once you spend the first 30 minutes going thru the tutorial *i recommend* your basicly ready to lay out something quickly and effectively. Starting is very simple and allows you to focus on the design and layout. While later slowly introducing elements that open up more economic strategy. City utilities are managed on a simpler and more macro size scale. You can create trade routes between two cities to share resources, *yet to explore it more* and so on. Basicly its enjoyable. Now for quality. This game has no more bugs than an average AAA title does that releases for “your console of choice” or any other system. I personally have not run into anything. I have a 2014 edition of the razer “blade pro” playing on full settings at 3k. I have not experienced any lag or slowdown. I average about 60 fps and dips down to about 45 fps while exploring on ground level. So im sure anyone with a mid core gaming desktop or consumer laptop should be able to run this ok. I have also managed to run it on low settings on a surface pro 3 i5 variant. Runs around 20fps, so hopefully that gives you a benchmark range of what to expect.Well what's with all Bad hype behind Cities XXL?Lets be real, what more do you want to see from this particular series? A future space theme skinned game that really gets no improvement in gameplay and just adds more bugs?If you are familiar with the Cities XL game and really enjoyed it for what it was, then you will like Cities XXL. Not a lot of re learning so we can focus more on what we love to do. Build huge gigantic cities! I dont have the biggest city yet *only been playing for about 3 hours on 5x speed* but so far iv not run into many hitches. Cities XXL is basicly the same thing as Simcity: Cities of tomorrow was. But less disappointing.To be fair in their advertising “at least from what i saw” never said it was going to be a new engine. And all the screenshots look like they might have been taken from Cities XL. So what did you expect when buying itt? I feel the game undertook some massive improvements as far as rendering, and speed. I treated this buy more like an expansion then a whole new game. Yes it does suck they did not just improve the old engine but. I mean we got multiple truck simulators, farm simulators, bus sim…..you get the idea. Only so much can be done with a game series that is so fragile right now no one wants screw anything up.They added steam workshop content to the game and which is like the developers giving us the tools to build whatever you want. So for the hardcore citie player you have nothing to complain about. If we give it a chance to grow it has the chance to become basically whatever we want.No online multiplayer, And honestly this should really be no surprise. Games like Anno and Simcity do not have the best track record of been successful at multiplayer online. Why risk breaking a perfectly playable game with multiplayer. We can still share cities with our friends.Steam workshop. Must i say more?In short i got exactly what i wanted. Hoping that the community will grasp it and love it for what i believe it deserves. 7/10 would buy again. I really want the creationist user to grasp modding this game. While i'm not looking for anything in particular it would be cool to see what people come up with.

number of helpful: 32 of 113 people (28%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												For those who already know and enjoy the franchise, Cities XXL is a must,  the 50% discount is a fair deal for Cities XL owners. The multi-core support is the most important feature of this release along with Steam Workshop integration for custom content.If you never played Cities XL, this could become your favourite city builder.The new UI though is not very different, looks better than the old one, at least it looks more stylish for today standards.  The new filter allows you to filter buildings by Architectural style, period, geographic location, etc. That's quite useful considering the game has tons of buildings and many more are constatly created by the modding community.The game overall feels and looks the same but the improvements are noticeable, the new skybox that allows you to select different environments (cloudy days, beautiful sunsets, etc) makes the cities look more alive and realistic.  The shadows were improved and the texture filtering is better (no blurry textures).There are some new buildings like freight airport, a new sport marina, bike rental, and many more including new transport related buildings like Park and Ride. Industries now can be upgraded to more eco-friendly versions.  There are no new residential buildings, though.The game's still not perfect, but still quiet enjoyable and no other game offers the graphic detail or the map sizes of CXXL.If you didn't like the previous versions, move along. It's likely you ain't gonna like this one either.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												No I don't recommend this game, ( a month or so in, and this is changing 2 patches already, things have improoved) it's (still) Cities XL, but buggier and laggier, but thats not the worst of it, some of the people on the forum are so hostile when you complain about the game. (No longer true, the forums have become a bastion of help and support, very good turn around, people are now free to complian about the game as well). There still are some issues with MODS causing crashes, and the 2 patches that were implementd did cause problems for some.I think I WOULD RECOMMEND this now, the MODS are excellent and it's kept me enthralled for nearly 125 hours I think.You may  need to be prepared for to do some tweaking though, there are step ny step instructions on the forum and it only happens around certain mods and patches.I'm REALLY ENJOYING IT NOW!

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Honestly, I expected more. Same old game with different UI. There is new structures but nothing like "WOW!" It would be more interesting if it was sold as an addon rather than a "new game" because there is nothing really "new" there. Also, its suffers from the same annoying CTDs, just like previous versions.This game is pratically a copy from the old one. I had put my mods folder from XL Platinum just for a little testing and guess what? IT WORKED!So, my sincere opinion: I recommend it on 2 conditions:1 - buy it when it in a very nice sale (50% off or more);2 - only if you appreciate the series and this kind of game.PS: Sorry for any grammar errors. I'm still learning english. :D
